Informative XML Examples for prEN 18223 This document provides informative XML examples that are exact corollaries to the optimized JSON serialization examples found in prEN 18223, Chapter 5.
XML Serialization Conventions These examples demonstrate the application of the conceptual model (Clause 4) and the optimized serialization rules (Clause 5) to an XML format. The serialization follows the naming conventions defined in prEN 18223, Clause 5.2.1: PascalCase for UML Classes and camelCase for attributes and elementIds.
The primary considerations when converting the optimized JSON format to XML involve the serialization of arrays (JSON arrays) and the management of namespaces.
Element Naming (Optimized Format): In the optimized representation, the elementId (the JSON object key) is used directly as the XML element tag name (e.g., ).
Root Elements: When an example serializes a complete class instance, the root element uses the Class name in PascalCase (e.g., or ).
Generic Arrays (MultiValuedDataElement): For MultiValuedDataElements where the items are generic (e.g., primitive types like numbers/strings, or anonymous DataElementCollection objects), the standardized tag name
shall be used for the repeating elements. This maintains simplicity and consistency.
Specific Arrays: When the array items correspond to a specific class defined in the conceptual model, the Class name (PascalCase) is used as the tag for the repeating elements. This applies specifically to the MultiLanguageDataElement, which uses the tag for its items (Section 4.1.2.8.1).
Namespaces (xmlns): Real-world XML implementations must use XML namespaces (defined via the xmlns attribute). This is essential for uniquely identifying elements and preventing naming conflicts, especially when combining data defined by the horizontal standard and different Content Specifications (Delegated Acts), as identified in the contentSpecificationIds field. The XML Namespace URI (which must be a valid URI) serves as the technical identifier for the specific vocabulary (XSD implementation). Namespace prefixes (e.g., specA:) are used to distinguish elements belonging to different schemas.
